Films 5 and 6 are almost exclusively "utilization" and should perhaps
he re-read in their skeletal-treatment form, as the comments indicate
that the readers have not grasped the emphasis of these treatments on
the importance of the teacher role.
Divesting the treatments of the material suggested and compressing
other material (which changes in style will permit) will certainly enable
us to put even more emphasis throughout the entire film series on ele¬
ments which the Advisory Committee and the Office of Education personnel
deem highly important: (l) the fact that television is not the end
and all of learning resources, hut simply a relatively new technology
in the school instructional program, another in the long line of resources
employed hy education in its continuing effort to improve the teaching-
learning process; (2) the fact that the role of the classroom teacher
is crucial in adapting stimulus to learning; (3) that activities which
are appropriate for developing skills are not necessarily those most
appropriate for developing attitudes or reinforcing knowledge or estab¬
lishing values, and that the efficacy of the activity is determined
hy how it relates to the goal to he achieved; (4) that the classroom teacher
must control the use of the television segment to create a wholesome,
dynamic learning situation and, conversely, that the television segment
must not control the classroom; (5) the fact that teaching can he improved
hy the use of television lessons because, when properly planned and pre¬
pared, and when used effectively, such lessons can promote effective
types of learning experience at all levels.
Illustrations in the present treatments were approved or suggested hy
the members of the Advisory Committee, hut the writer, as previously
and vehemently stated on several occasions, welcomes and urges assistance
in determining which are the best illustrations to he used in specific
instances. In the next stage of development these will specifically
he solicited from the Advisoiy Committee.
The original plan for the films suggests that the kits will he so designed
that they can he used either in sequence or as individual presentations.
As it is urged hy those contemplating final review and approval that
scripts should he related to one another and suggested that there should
be a bridge from one film to another, attention will be given to doing
this. Attention also will he given to designing one or more programs
